Name: Linear Programming
Description: A technique to achieve the best outcome in a mathematical model whose requirements are represented by linear relationships. It involves a linear objective function and linear constraints.
Appearances: The Diet Problem: finding the cheapest combination of foods that satisfies all the daily nutritional requirements.

Name: Mixed-Integer Linear Programming
Description: An extension of LP where some or all of the decision variables are restricted to be integer values. This allows for modeling discrete choices (e.g., yes/no decisions).
Solvability: NP-hard. Solvability in practice depends heavily on the problem structure; can be very difficult for large instances.
Example: Facility Location: deciding where to build warehouses to minimize total shipping costs.

Name: Nonlinear Programming
Description: A broad class of problems where either the objective function or one or more of the constraints are nonlinear functions of the decision variables.
Solvability: Varies greatly. Non-convex NLPs are very hard to solve globally and algorithms may only find a local optimum.
Example: Optimal Power Flow: determining the most efficient power generation levels in an electrical grid.

Name: Quadratic Programming
Description: A type of NLP where the objective function is a quadratic function of the decision variables and the constraints are linear.
Solvability: Efficiently solvable if the objective function is convex; otherwise it is NP-hard.
Example: Markowitz Portfolio Optimization: finding the asset allocation that minimizes risk (variance) for a given level of expected return.

Name: Convex Optimization
Description: A subfield of optimization that studies the problem of minimizing convex functions over convex sets. This structure guarantees that any local optimum is also a global optimum.
Solvability: Generally considered efficiently solvable. Includes LP and convex QP as special cases.
Example: Support Vector Machine (SVM): finding the optimal hyperplane to separate data points in machine learning.

Name: Combinatorial Optimization
Description: Problems focused on finding an optimal object from a finite set of objects. The problem space is discrete and often involves graphs; structures; and permutations.
Solvability: Most non-trivial problems are NP-hard. Often solved using MIP formulations or specialized algorithms.
Example: The Traveling Salesperson Problem (TSP): finding the shortest possible route that visits each city exactly once and returns to the origin city.

Name: Stochastic Programming
Description: A framework for modeling optimization problems that involve uncertainty. Some of the parameters (e.g.; customer demand; prices) are unknown and are modeled as random variables.
Solvability: Computationally very intensive. Often much harder to solve than their deterministic counterparts.
Example: Inventory Management under Uncertainty: deciding how much stock to hold when future demand is not known for certain.

Name: Dynamic Programming
Description: An algorithmic technique for solving complex problems by breaking them down into a collection of simpler; overlapping subproblems. It is suited for problems with optimal substructure.
Solvability: Efficient if the state space is manageable. Can suffer from the ""curse of dimensionality"" where the state space grows exponentially.
Example: Shortest Path Problems: finding the path with the minimum cost between two nodes in a graph (e.g.; Bellman-Ford algorithm).

Name: Constraint Programming
Description: A paradigm for solving combinatorial problems by stating constraints over a set of variables with specific domains. The solver systematically finds a feasible solution by propagating constraints.
Solvability: Effective for highly constrained problems like scheduling and timetabling where finding a feasible solution is the main challenge.
Example: Exam Timetabling: assigning university exams to time slots such that no student has a conflict.

Name: Heuristics and Metaheuristics
Description: A category of solution methods used for problems that are too complex or large to be solved optimally. These methods aim to find a good; feasible solution in a reasonable amount of time without guaranteeing optimality.
Solvability: Provides approximate solutions quickly. The quality of the solution is not guaranteed.
Example: Genetic Algorithms for Vehicle Routing: finding good-enough routes for a fleet of delivery vehicles in a very large city.
